Description: Numerous joining and unjoining fragments, including handle roots, of a South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: glazed black with reserved band below rim and reserved tondo with two black rings; exterior: narrow black line at top of rim, rest of rim reserved; glazed below save reserved band in handle zone; underside of foot reserved; inscription on exterior.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Dimensions: Height: 5.50 centimetres (upper body with handle root)
Height: 5 centimetres (upper body with part of handle root)
Thickness: 1 centimetres (upper body with handle root)
Thickness: 0.70 centimetres (upper body with part of handle root)
Width: 12 centimetres (upper body with handle root)
Width: 8 centimetres (upper body with part of handle root)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd,the shape and decoration find parallels with his South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9A. The type closely follows the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18), Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116), and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.274) (Phase 3)
